subject: RE: [junit] Separate Assertion Object
msgSnippet: Hello again, One thing I forgot to mention is that EJUF aims to provide complete backwards compatibility with JUnit... Thanks ! Francois On Mon, 03 Feb 2003
messageBody:
Hello again,

One thing I forgot to mention is that EJUF aims to provide complete
backwards compatibility with JUnit...

Thanks !
Francois

On Mon, 03 Feb 2003 12:37:06 -0500, "Francois Beausoleil"
<fbeausoleil@...> said:
> Hello everyone,
>
> I have a project on SourceForge.net which I started a while ago. I named
> it "Extensible Java Unit-testing Framework" (ejuf for short). This
> project is using a reusable assertion mechanism. I am using the Jakarta
> "Byte Code Engineering Library" to implement assertion interfaces into
> testable objects.
>
> For example, let's say you want to use XML assertions and DB assertions
> in the same test case, you would do something like this:
> public abstract MyXmlAndDbCase implements Testable, XmlAssertions,
> DbAssertions, EqualityAssertions {
> public void testSomething() {
> // Uses an object that implements XmlAssertions that was previously
> configured
> assertXmlEquals(...);
>
> // Uses an object that implements DbAssertions that was previously
> configured
> assertDbEquals(...); // I don't know actual method names, but this
> is for illustration purposes
>
> // Uses an object that implements EqualityAssertions that was
> previously configured
> assertEquals(...);
> }
> }
>
> This way of doing things provides me with a completely vendor and
> extension neutral way of doing things. Additionnaly, I have other things
> in there to help testing.
>
> For more information, you may access the project's CVS repository. I
> have successfully used EJUF in two or three projects of mine. Obviously,
> EJUF is able to test itself :)
>
> I consider the code ready for prime-time, except that there is almost no
> documentation. WARNING: There is a failure in the tests right now
> because that is where I left off. I had started doing XmlConfiguration
> stuff, but that is not finished. But the rest is actually very usable.
>
> If you want to take a look at the project and report back, I would be
> more than happy to help and respond to comments, although such
> discussions might be more appropriate on EJUF's mailing lists...
>
> Thank you,
> Francois Beausoleil
> http://sourceforge.net/projects/ejuf/
>
> On Mon, 3 Feb 2003 10:49:57 +0900 (JST), "Curt Sampson"
> <yahoo_sucks@...> said:
> > On Sun, 2 Feb 2003, Scott Stirling wrote:
> >
> > > Why not just extend TestCase with specialized, re-usable, TestCase types?
> >
> > I do already. In fact, many times: we have a base test case for our
> > company which adds various handy generic stuff (such as byte-array
> > comparisons), inheriting from that often a test case for a project
> > adding some project specific-stuff, inheriting from that in certain
> > packages a package-specific test case adding stuff for the servlet or
> > DB testing or whatever, and so on.
> >
> > Unfortunately, it's not very modular; if someone supplies me with
> > a ExtendedTestCaseOne and another person supplies me with an
> > ExtendedTestCaseTwo, each of which has certain features I want, I can't
> > inherit from both. And again, the test cases tend to collect more and
> > more code, becoming this massive objects with massive functionality (and
> > correspondingly massive tests)....
> >
> > My primary feeling here (whether supportable or not) is that a TestCase
> > could be a lot smaller and simpler if we could move most of the
> > assertion checking and assertion message generation code out of it.
> > As well it would also give us the ability to easily add different
> > ways of asserting where and when we need them, without having to use
> > inheritance to bring in new implemenations of something. (I'm a big fan
> > of type inheritance; I'm rather dubious about the use of inheritance for
> > implemenation purposes only.)
> >
> > cjs
> > --
> > Curt Sampson <cjs@...> +81 90 7737 2974 http://www.netbsd.org
> > Don't you know, in this new Dark Age, we're all light. --XTC
